body: I think it critical, thanks for the issue

hmm yeah I see. The worker entrypoint is side-effect-free, so it thinks nothing is needed at all, but still included it. So it probably should either create a empty worker bundle (as there is no side effect, so everything can be removed), or implicitly marking worker entries as non-side-effect-free, or emitting an error/warning that side-effect-free modules can't be used as worker entries since this doesn't have any effect.

> or implicitly marking worker entries as non-side-effect-free

I think this would be the expected behaviour, Workers are more similar to entry points than modules. Or would you exclude application entry point too when `sideEffects: false` is present?

> Or would you exclude application entry point too when `sideEffects: false` is present?

Would make sense. But at least there should be a warning, as one is incorrectly making it as side-effect-free.

Once you wrap it into a new entry with `import "./old-entry.js"` it would be excluded... That seems a bit inconsistent...

---

I tried

``` js
// package.json
	"sideEffects": [
		"./worker.js"
	],
```

that fixes the problem.

---

btw.

``` js
    splitChunks: {
      chunks: 'all',
      minSize: 0,
      usedExports: false
    }
```

will put `utils.js` into it's own chunk

> Would make sense. But at least there should be a warning, as one is incorrectly making it as side-effect-free.

Idk, to me personally entry points being excluded from default side-effect-free list felt like a feature not a bug ðŸ˜… So I thought Workers could be naturally excluded too.

> Idk, to me personally entry points being excluded from default side-effect-free list felt like a feature not a bug

yeah, just found code that enforces entrypoints to to be considered as having side-effects^^

> yeah, just found code that enforces entrypoints to to be considered as having side-effects^^

Ah, so it _is_ intended. Good to know.

In that case Workers should probably be handled in the same way.

issue.title: enforce side-effects on async entries similar to normal entrypoints

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

body: Ok there is a fix, but I still want to note that your worker files is incorrectly flagged as side-effect-free and we might add a warning for that in future. Also for entrypoints.

That was quick. Thanks!

In this case I don't have much control over `sideEffects: false` (it's generated by wasm-pack, and it's been unmtaintained for some time now), so a fix at least for now is surely helpful.

> will put `utils.js` into it's own chunk

Interesting, why is `usedExports` used by default? It seems like sharing at least a subset of code is always benefitial?

> will put `utils.js` into it's own chunk

I actually think I found another bug :(

issue.title: Worker chunking makes main app bundle to no-op

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template because we'll close your issue -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->

# Bug report

In #12646, I've used this demo with `sideEffects:false` https://glitch.com/edit/#!/grass-northern-xenon.

The original issue was solved, but on the same thread @sokra suggested:

> btw.
>
> ``` js
>     splitChunks: {
>       chunks: 'all',
>       minSize: 0,
>       usedExports: false
>     }
> ```
> 
> will put `utils.js` into it's own chunk

as a way to force code-splitting between main JS and the worker.

This seems to trigger another bug: when I use those settings, the main JS no longer calls `initWorker`, a new thread is not created, and the console on https://grass-northern-xenon.glitch.me/ stays empty.

If I comment out e.g. `minSize: 0`, then everything works and `42` is printed in the console as expected.

Note that this time I don't even use `sideEffects: false`, so the issues are likely not related to each other.

**Other relevant information:**
webpack version: 5.21.2
Node.js version: 14.15.2

issue.title: Self-reference dependency has unused export name when imported inside of a web worker

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template because we'll close your issue -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->

# Bug report

<!-- Please ask questions on StackOverflow or the GitHub Discussions. -->
<!-- https://github.com/webpack/webpack/discussions -->
<!-- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/ask?tags=webpack -->
<!-- Issues which contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->

**What is the current behavior?**

When a web worker imports a CommonJS module with a self reference dependency, webpack throws `Error: Self-reference dependency has unused export name: This should not happen`.

This happens when `usedExports` is set to `"global"`.

I think this is related:
https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/12646 / https://github.com/webpack/webpack/pull/12648

It seems like that fix works when `usedExports` is not set to `"global"`, but it doesn't work when `usedExports: "global"` is set.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce.**

Repro: https://github.com/pgoldberg/webpack-self-reference-dependency-worker-bug

<!-- A great way to do this is to provide your configuration via a GitHub repository -->
<!-- The most helpful is a minimal reproduction with instructions on how to reproduce -->
<!-- Repositories with too many files or large `webpack.config.js` files are not suitable -->
<!-- Please only add small code snippets directly into this issue -->
<!-- https://gist.github.com is a good place for longer code snippets -->
<!-- If your issue is caused by a plugin or loader, please create an issue on the loader/plugin repository instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**

Webpack should not throw an error

**Other relevant information:**
webpack version:  5.91.0
Node.js version: any
Operating System: any
Additional tools:
